note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

note.p: Christopher Gustavus Memminger was an author of the Provisional Constitution of the Confederate States of America and the first Secretary of the Treasury for the Confederacy. Born on January 9, 1803, in Vaihingen, Wuerttemberg (modern-day Stuttgart, Germany), Memminger moved to Charleston, South Carolina, as a small child with his mother after his father passed away. He was orphaned in 1807 when his mother died of yellow fever, but at the age of eleven was taken in by Thomas Bennett, future governor of South Carolina. At age twelve, Memminger entered South Carolina College and graduated at the age of sixteen. He studied law and became a practicing attorney in 1825. Memminger became involved in the 1830s, winning an election to the South Carolina state legislature in 1836 and served almost continuously until 1860. He chaired the legislature’s finance committee for most of his time in office.

Memminger was considered a moderate among southerners during the growing sectional crisis. He opposed South Carolina’s proponents of nullification (the theory that a state could reject a federal law it opposed) and was hesitant to support calls for secession during the 1850s. However, after Abraham Lincoln was elected president on an anti-slavery Republican platform in 1860, Memminger became an advocate for disunion and wrote the proclamation outlining South Carolina’s secession from the Union, entitled Declaration of the Immediate Causes Which Induce and Justify the Secession of South Carolina from the Federal Union.

Memminger was elected to represent South Carolina in the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States. He chaired the committee that drafted a constitution for the Confederacy in four days, and then received an appointment as Secretary of the Treasury in February 1861. In that role he struggled to finance the Confederate war effort, resorting to supporting income taxes, widespread issuing of paper money, and even confiscating gold from the U.S. Mint in New Orleans. Memminger served as Treasury secretary until July 1864, then resigned and retired to his summer home in North Carolina.

After the Civil War, Memminger returned to Charleston, South Carolina, and operated a law practice. He also returned to the state legislature, dedicating much of his time to improving South Carolina’s public education system. He died on March 7, 1888, in Charleston. Memminger was married to Mary Wilkinson and had seventeen children (only eight survived to adulthood). After Mary passed away in 1874, Memminger married her sister Sarah Ann. Memminger is buried in Saint John in the Wilderness Cemetery in Flat Rock, North Carolina.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Louise Howe Bailey, “Memminger, Christopher Gustavus,” NCPedia; National Park Service)

gloss.p: The Confederate Army was the military land force of the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Known also as the Confederate States Army or Southern Army, it was established by the Provisional Confederate Congress in February 1861 and fell under the authority of Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Modeled after the U.S. Army of the 19th century, the Confederate Army technically fell into two categories: a small regular army of professional officers and soldiers (the Army of the Confederate States of America) and a much larger, temporary force of citizen soldiers intended to exist only for the duration of the war (the Provisional Army of the Confederate States). In reality, the Confederacy’s regular army never fully developed and the overwhelming majority of Confederate soldiers served in the provisional force. The distinction between the two played little role during military operations and all were generally considered to be part of the overall Confederate Army.

As many as 1,000,000 soldiers served in the Confederate Army between 1861 and 1865, although not all at one time. Most were volunteers, however, the Confederate government instituted a conscription (or draft) in April 1862—the first in U.S. or Confederate history—to increase the size of the Confederacy’s military force and encourage voluntary enlistment. The government passed two more conscription acts over the next two years. More than ten percent of the men who served in Confederate ranks were drafted.

Over ninety percent of soldiers in the Confederate Army were native-born white men. Nine percent were foreign-born white men. Several Native American units—particularly from the Cherokee, Creek, and Choctaw tribes—served within the Confederate military, especially in the trans-Mississippi theatre. The Confederate military heavily relied upon the forced labor of enslaved African Americans for building fortifications and carrying out menial tasks, and the Confederate government did not formally allow African Americans (free or slave) to join the army until a last minute desperate measure passed the Confederate Congress in March 1865, only weeks before the end of the war. Only around two hundred enslaved soldiers were organized into service, but they were not sent into combat.

By the time the last Confederate soldiers surrendered to Union forces in June 1865, nearly 100,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 160,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia)

The Congress of the Confederate States of America was established by Article 1 of the Confederate States Constitution on March 11, 1861 in Montgomery, Alabama. Operating at the national level of the Confederacy, it was the Legislative Branch of the Confederate States government responsible for making and amending laws. A bicameral body, the Confederate States Congress was divided into the upper house (Senate) and the lower house (House of Representatives). The Confederate States Congress concluded Its final session on March 18, 1865. (Avalon Project-Constitution of the Confederate States; March 11, 1861; Wikipedia)

Operating nationally, the Provisional Confederate Congress established the Department of Treasury by an act on February 21, 1861 in Montgomery, Alabama. The department was led by the Secretary of the Treasury appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate. It was initially led by Christopher Memminger from February 21, 1861–July 18, 1864 and later by George Trenholm (July 18, 1864–April 27, 1865) and John Henninger Reagan (April 27–May 10, 1865). The Department of Treasury was responsible to superintend the collection of the public revenue and expenditures and advising the President and the Congress on all matters related to finance. (Acts and Resolutions of the First Session of the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States, 1861 Public Laws, S1, 43; Wikipedia)

div.p:
N Orleans Nov 11/61
Charles G Johnson
Hon J J Pettus
Your Excellency

Enclosed I hand you "a well considered scheme" for creating a Circulating medium for our people, There exists an [admitted?] necessity for the Confed=erate Congress to provide for us a Currency, and if it fails to do so it will be for the want of an adequate and definite plan.

It is not only the right but the first duty of every Govern-ment to provide for its people a Circulating medium—for with=out it no Government can exist, it is the vital current that inspires its life,

The Constitution confers upon Congress the undoubted right to "coin money and measure values," and in the absence of Bullion it has the unquestionable right to substitute cotton and tobacco as a measure of value, and to issue its notes upon them
as a basis of Currency under the plan I propose they are super=ior to gold and silver, for they have not only a Conventional but a real value_ while that of gold and silver is only Con-ventional.
The objection to the scheme that it is giving Governmental aid to private enterprise, will not hold against this plan

The Goverment is ready nay anxious to advance its notes upon the silver of Peru mined by individual enterprise_ and because it is willing to do this, will these sapient political econ-omists of the Memminger school insists that it must also ad=vance its notes upon the Bull's Pizzles of Patagonia.

The Planter holds the value, is the unpaid and se=curely bound Custodionian of of the goverment, it is true he in the first instance receives the notes, but they immediately go in to Circulation to pay for the

grain of the grain States, the Sugar of Louisiana—and the labor of the mechanic all classes, and all trades and occupations are alike benefitted, the "coining" this surplus wealth of the Country will give an impetus to trade and to manufactures_ and will at once destroy the evil effects of the blockade, in fact will make it a positive good.

The impotency of Mr Mem=minger's administration has cost the Country millions, and if he persists in the course he has a=dopted will involve us in utter ruin, nine months he has been at the head of the finance and as yet his department is not an organism, but is dependent upon the voluntary contributions of the people for its supplies, the people have clothed fed and moved the army, and for all purposes of good the secratary has been a Dummy on the board, all of his meas-ures have been pregnant with

evil—he has drawn the Capital of the Country into the hands of speculators_ forced our Banks to suspend (a pitiable spectacle indeed a great nation on its knees to a few petty Corporations begging them, to remove the only remaining standard of values in the Country in order that its issues might Circulate) and placed us in a most deplorable situation, he has absorbed the individual Capital of the Country [unclear] down to the "old clothes," and now he is begging the Banks for theirs_
Your Excellency, in your message you suggest the only true policy_ All goverments meet their extraordinary ex=penses with their credit_our's must_and happy is it that it can do so use its Credit

which are greater than would at first appear_for there is no justice in opening and permitting shipmts from one Port while all others are closed. If Foreign nations do not take our cotton and tobacco we will plant no more until we use up the present Crop ourselves but it is hardly probable that Europe will suffer for a great while the total interruption of Fifteen hundred millions of her trade.
The Form of the enclosed plan is as follow's
The Goverment recognizes only the States in the transaction Deb-iting by the Governor's and cred=iting by the collector's.
The Secratary furnishes each Govenor with a sufficient amount of Notes to be countersigned by his officers.
John B. [Patten?] planter of Hinds makes one hundred bales cotton
Applies to the Sheriff gives the required guarantees_ and receives the advance on 100 B/c a 2500 $2,500

with its own people, & must issue its notes and make them a legal tender_ to say that the State or that the people of the States will not sanction a measure necess=ary for the preservation of their lib-erty, is to insult their intelligence and impugn their patriotism,
The cotton law, Mr Menninger's "saving idea" is unjust in its pro=visions and impracticable in its execution.

The Planter must pay his debts before he Can subscribe to the loan, the Merchant must sell the Cotton that owes him money before he Can sell that subscribed to the loan. Consequently the Goverment cotton will be carried over until next Season probably until dooms-day and the liberal and patriotic planter, [sacrificed] to this ignus faatus, of Mr Menninger, and his man Friday the historian of the grand idea J. B. D. De Boid
By "coining" the foreign exports we at once get rid of all the dif=ficulties regarding their shipment
The Sheriff reports to the Govenor (and ^or^ his appointed officer) and John Pettus is charged on the State Book's $2,500.

The Cotton is shipped as usual to the Merchant, who Sells it for say, 5000 pr bale nett. The Merchant pays over to the Collector the nett proceeds say 5,00000 and receives a receipt and a Certificate that will enable the buyer to move the Cotton.

The Collector at once reports to the Govenoror_ received from merchant nett proceeds 100 B/c sold for a/c John Pettus_ 500000, and the amt is placed to his Pettus's Credit on the State Books. The Govenor then through his Agt the Sheriff_ issues to Pettus the balance due him in Confederate Bonds_ say $2500 less 1/2 "/" which which suffice to pay all the expense of the transaction

I would make these notes issued upon cotton "Fundable" this would secure to the goverment an ac=tual loan of the entire proceeds of the Cotton and tobacco crops and at the same time give the people a Circulating medium
as good to them as gold and silver if it is issued so it cannot be counterfeited, and is made on legal tender.
Your Excellency I have not time to elaborate this matter. I have labored to diffuse these ideas since last June, and when fully explained I have yet to find one who has not cordially approved

Under your administration our noble old mother has assumed a proud position_grant her sovereignty_ to her children she is first_ and all_ true to herself she will ever prove true to her allies of the Confed=eracy
Yours truly
The enclosed Article has been extensively published_and approved_
Would it not be well to frame a Bill and instruct our Delagates to vote for it_
